title: Issue with hypermorph (--image-sigma and sampling distribution)
body:
**Task** (what are you trying to do/register?)

Hello, I am trying to register 3D head&neck CT images and use hypermorph to find the best regularization parameters.

**What have you tried**

Question 1 (--image-sigma):
I first trained with the default --image-sigma in train_hypermorph.py (0.05). The results didn't look good probably due to the mse loss being scaled too large. Then I tried --image-sigma =1 and it worked much better. I found in another issue saying --image-sigma hasn't been really used (https://github.com/voxelmorph/voxelmorph/issues/408). So I just want to make sure: do I need to have a good estimation of image noise or I can just ignore this hyperparameter by setting it to 1.

Question 2 (hyperparameter sampling distribution):
L = L_sim + γ * L_reg (γ ∈ [0,+∞])
L = (1-λ) * L_sim + λ * L_reg (λ ∈ [0,1])
I noticed in train_hypermorph.py that λ is uniformly sampled from [0,1]. If the optimal γ is too small or too large (e.g. γ* = 0.01, λ* = 0.0099; γ* = 100, λ* = 0.99), very few samples will be drawn around the optimal value. Will this be an issue? My personal intuition is that if we don't have any prior knowledge about the optimal λ or γ, we could design the distribution of λ such that the corresponding distribution of γ is log uniform. The end-point oversampling (code below) seems to be addressing this issue, but why only oversampling exactly at the endpoint instead of oversampling around the endpoint. I am wondering if you have already conducted any experiment showing that this strategy is robust no matter what value the optimal λ takes?                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    
```
# random hyperparameter generator
def random_hyperparam():
    if np.random.rand() < args.oversample_rate:
        return np.random.choice([0, 1])
    else:
        return np.random.rand()              
```                                                                                                                                                                                                           

Thanks in advance for any help and thank you for this fantastic work!
